title: Guests slam 'shambles' holiday park after mass norovirus outbreak leaves 90 ill
text:

Guests at a holiday park where around 90 people fell ill from a mass sickness outbreak have claimed the handling of the situation was a "shambles".

One mum described the scene at Mullion Holiday Park in Cornwall yesterday as "horrific" and claimed kids were "dropping like flies".

The park has temporarily closed as a precaution as the facilities are cleaned following the norovirus outbreak, reports Cornwall Live.

Park chiefs initially said they believed the illness originated off site.

Richard Marlborough was among the visitors to fall violently ill. He arrived at the site on Monday with two other motorcyclist friends from Manchester, Kieran Lowe and Mark Mawby.

(Image: Cornwall Live WS)

They claim they had to beg for disinfectant to clean their caravan when cleaners allegedly refused to come in and do it themselves.

Richard, who was the first of the friends to fall ill, said: “The situation started on Wednesday evening around 8pm.

"We were in the bar and saw kids being violently sick. As soon as someone was sick, someone else would start.

“A sign was placed over the sick and not cleaned for over 30 minutes. A few minutes later a security guard requested a cleaner to someone else being sick in the female toilets.”

The friends claim no announcements were made by staff to alert guests to the sickness or give advice.

Richard said: “I was starting to feel sick and had stomach cramps. On returning to the caravan I lay down in severe pain and within minutes I was violently sick to the point security knocked on the door to see if I was okay.

(Image: Cornwall Live WS)

“My friends were going to ring an ambulance for me as I’ve got a pacemaker, so I’ve got to be careful.

“Throughout the night I was constantly sick and my friend started with it around 1.30am.

"We were up all night, then we went to reception and they wouldn’t give us any advice, only a statement to say a doctor had been on site but they wouldn’t tell us what it was.”

Richard’s other friend started being violently ill at around 10am on Thursday.

“They just gave us a form each to fill in and we are not being kept up to date. We still have not been told what this illness is – we are learning more from reading Cornwall Live.”

Richard added: “We asked a cleaner to come in and clean our caravan but they refused as they didn’t want to catch it.

"I said, give me disinfectant and a cloth and I’ll do it. They said they weren’t allowed to give me any cleaning equipment. They must have seen the look on my face as they eventually gave me a pack of Dettol wipes.”

(Image: Cornwall Live WS)

He claimed that a bag of their bedding, covered in sick, was still in a big bag outside their caravan.

The men say they will now cancel a return visit to the park in 2020.

“They don’t seem to be cleaning up the bags full of sick bedding. Every caravan has got bags of sick bedding outside," said Richard, who added that security and a number of staff were doing their best but there was no sign of management.

“I’ve just asked reception and they are refusing to give us any info, just saying the site facilities are closed and there are no more check-ins but they will still not confirm what the virus is. It's an absolute shambles.”

Another guest, Scott Clarke, said the first he knew of what appears to be a norovirus bug is when another family told him.

He said: “There was no explanation from anyone who works at the park. The first we knew was when we tried to go up the arcade with the kids yesterday and another guest stopped us, then we saw it on the news, so very disappointed.

(Image: Google)

"The whole park needs a bloody good clean, sad really as my wife has holidayed here since a child but we won’t be returning again.”

A spokesperson for Mullion Holiday Park said: “We immediately contacted Public Health England and the local environmental health authority once we were made aware that some guests on the park were ill.

"We worked closely with the authorities throughout the day and they visited the park yesterday and told us they are happy with the measures we have in place.

“We have taken the decision to temporarily close, as a precaution. We are extremely sorry to everybody this will affect, however the health and wellbeing of our guests is paramount.

"Wherever possible, we are providing alternative accommodation for our guests and owners.”

He added that all public areas and accommodation will all be professionally cleaned. Items for washing may have been placed outside caravans while the interiors are being cleaned, he said.

Refunds are being offered to guests.
description: Richard Marlborough was among the visitors to fall violently ill at Mullion Holiday Park in Cornwall and claims he had to beg for disinfectant to clean his caravan
